review.title: A Multistage Stochastic Programming Approach to the Dynamic and Stochastic VRPTW - Extended version
review.abstract: We consider a dynamic vehicle routing problem with time windows and stochastic customers (DS-VRPTW), such that customers may request for services as vehicles have already started their tours. To solve this problem, the goal is to provide a decision rule for choosing, at each time step, the next action to perform in light of known requests and probabilistic knowledge on requests likelihood. We introduce a new decision rule, called Global Stochastic Assessment (GSA) rule for the DS-VRPTW, and we compare it with existing decision rules, such as MSA. In particular, we show that GSA fully integrates nonanticipativity constraints so that it leads to better decisions in our stochastic context. We describe a new heuristic approach for efficiently approximating our GSA rule. We introduce a new waiting strategy. Experiments on dynamic and stochastic benchmarks, which include instances of different degrees of dynamism, show that not only our approach is competitive with state-of-the-art methods, but also enables to compute meaningful offline solutions to fully dynamic problems where absolutely no a priori customer request is provided.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Dynamic (or online) vehicle routing problems (D-VRPs) arise when information about requirements is incomplete, e.g. when a customer is able to submit a request during the online execution of a solution.D-VRP instances usually refer to the deterministic requirements, i.e., those that are known before the online process, if at all. Whenever additional (stochastic) knowledge of unknown requests is available, the problem is referred to as stochastical. We focus on dynamic and stochastic VRPs with time windows (DS-VRPTW).These problems occur in many practical situations, such as door-to-and-hospital transportation of elderly or disabled people. In many countries, authorities try to set up Dial-a-Ride services, but the operating costs and complexity of satisfying all customer requirements quickly become untenable.

[20] In this section, we focus in particular on stochastic approaches to stochastic D-VRP in two categories, either based on stochastic modeling or on sampling. Stochastic modeling approaches formally capture the stochastic nature of the problem, so that solutions are calculated in the light of a general stochastic context. Such holistic approaches usually require strong assumptions and efficient calculation of complex expected values. Sampling approaches attempt to capture stochastic knowledge through sampling, so that they tend to focus more on local stochastic decisions.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: We proposed GSA, a decision-making rule for dynamic and stochastic vehicle guidance with time windows (DS-VRPTW), based on a stochastic heuristic programming approach. Existing related studies, such as MSA, simplify the problem as a two-step problem by using average sample approximation. In contrast, the theoretical singularity of our method is to approach a multi-step stochastic problem through Monte Carlo random samples, using a heuristic evaluation function that maintains the non-anticipatory limitations. By maintaining a unique predictive solution that is designed as flexibly as possible according to a number of scenarios, our method differs in practice from the MSA, which calculates as many solutions as scenarios, each specializing in its associated scenario. Experimental results show that GSA achieves competitive results in terms of the state of the art. This paper also proposes a new resettlement strategy that only aims at calculating the benefit and the wait-and-see strategy.
